captions.text: RokuKazami asks
Dear Simon and Martina,
I was wondering how you felt about Dongho leaving
I know that you guys are mad close homies with U-Kiss
So maybe you could provide some insight
Thanks, Yo~
U-Kiss. Mad props, Son.
So I know that a lot of you will be watching this video
because you know that we have a bit of a relationship with U-Kiss
So you're going to be wondering if we had any secret information
About why Dongho left.
As opposes to his reason
And the answer is Yes.
Dongho didn't leave because of what he said he left for
He is leaving U-Kiss because he wants to pursue his career
as a Brazilian pirate.
Captain Donghoooo~
Prettiest boy of the seven seas~
Yar, I will drink your rum and take those girls with that pair of my shoulders.
Stop girl! And hand over your ship!
As you can see that is Not the real reason.
And we don't actually have any more information for you apart from what we read in the article
Yes, we did not ask them.
We're not in a place to.
So for those of you who don't know
Dongho is from U-Kiss and he officially...
[S]Don't know, Dong-Ho
Coffee is working!
As I was saying, Dongho said that he left U-Kiss because
he is really worried about his health
and he really wants to just live a normal life
And he absolutely can not pursue that while being a K-pop idol
Now there very well could be other reasons as of why he left
But from what he suggested, let me just say...
I don't blame him.
I totally understand.
Now we don't want to make this TL;DR on Donho alone
but instead we want to focus on the pressures of the K-pop world
And Why someone might be tempted to leave it.
Because let me say...
If I was in the K-pop world, I'd leave after probably day 1.
I might make it 2 days, but that's about it.
I don't think you should have signed that 7-year contract then, Simon
Noooo  waaay...
Now from our experiences and observations of the K-pop world
a little bit more behind the scenes than most people
We can honestly say that you couldn't pay us enough money to be a K-pop idol
because the Cons Clearly outweigh the Pros.
And this is just from Our perspective,  for other people they might have different values and morals
but from what We value most in life, we would never want to be K-pop idols
Too many Cons for me
Shitty thing #1:
Work hours.
So I feel like most K-pop fans have a vague understanding of how hard the K-pop idols work
They Know that they work hard, but do they know How crazy their schedule is?
So most groups will have a few concerts a Day!
Not a week, a day!
Depending on their schedule they could be on a TV program
Or it could be an actual concert.  It could be a radio show.
And they are just driving and bouncing from place to place every day
It's crazy!
They'll do one concert in the morning, get in the van, drive two hours away
do another concert, get in the van and drive three hours away for another concert
All in the same day.
No breaks, no nothing.
You're sleeping in vans, you're eating in vans, that's crazy.
So you know that we interviewed Crayon Pop a little while ago
and when they came in they were just So exhausted...
And after our event they were going to another event hours away
Then performing in another event and on the next day
SooZee ran into them performing at an event that she was going to
Back in Seoul.
That had nothing to do with K-pop
But they are doing all these different events that you may not actually know about.
That's tiring.
So it's like awesome that you have a successful song and single
But guess what? Now  you're going to be working mad crazy hours to promote that.
Not only are you working really crazy sucky hours
But also the conditions in which you work also are kind of crazy and sucky.
Yeah, like that backstage. We've seen a lot of backstages and Green Rooms now
I was really surprised. You might have heard about K-pop idols sleeping on the ground,
or the benches or chairs, little posts like instagram photos of them falling asleep
in weird places. And that's because there's nowhere else for them to sleep.
And when people do Music Video shoots,
it's not like they shoot a music video in a course of 3 days or a week.
They get this all done in one day, non-stop.
They are taking split-shifts as of who is sleeping on the changing room floor.
It looks all cute and endearing when everyone's all snuggled up
But really, that sucks to sleep on floors!
That's not a restful sleep, my friends.
Even Brad from BuskerBusker, which was the most successful band of 2012
You would think that their Super Star status would treat them any different
But no. they worked Insane!
If you want, you can actually read the article about it in Vice.
It's crazy what these guys went through.
And that's not even Half of what happened.
They can't write Everything.
It'll be a Book!
Good lick being a vegetarian.
Whoahahoa
Here's some rice.
When I was still living in North America
I've been backstage a couple of times for TV-shows, or had friends who were make-up artists
Or people who did movie sets, and even the most basic movie
run by students. Will have catering
Small little indie sets have pretty decent food
that is being fed to the people there.
But in Korea, it just seems to be like... normal Korean delivery
And not even really good delivery.
Just whatever local delivery is around.
Here's a Donkas, here's a Kimbap.
It's the cheapest delivery.
Or if they can't get you delivery, they'll just go to a convenience store,
and they'll grab all the chips and cookies they can find and will be like
"Here, eat a bunch of chips and cookies before you perform."
What I don't get about it is that I understand that there is the actual TV-show
and there is the actual concert/venue that's hosting it
but then it should be up to the individual companies to say
"No! My K-pop group needs to have green vegetable smoothies"
"Or they need to have This kind of food. This is what they want backstage"
But you see this kind of thing falling through when you hear about girls going on diets.
CRAZY DIETS!
It's like...
One was recent with IU.
She had to lose 8lbs
and weigh what? She was 18lbs before, she's 10lbs.
She's a very small girl.
And her diet was like "I... for a day I would eat a potato  and an apple"
And that's he whole freakin diet!
Why would you sound like GD?
A-Yo!
The point is that I think a company should be taking care of their K-pop idol
And if they have to go an a diet, it should be a healthy one.
It shouldn't be this crappy work environment
where they're like "YOU'RE FAT! LOSE WEIGHT! DRINK THIS WATER!"
and that's it for five days.
What solid did you have today? "An ice-cube?"
"I had some air?"
It doesn't count. That's not good. That's not a healthy work environment.
And it's not a good role-model for the rest of Korean girls as well.
Why is it going on record like a normal thing you talk about?
These people are Idols. They are called Idols for a reason.
People look up to them.
So if they are giving these shitty diets to little kids, they are going to grow up eating the same stuff.
Another terrible thing about the work conditions which you've all read about
How about the fact if you brake your ankle or sprain you neck or get into a car accident
You still have to perform!
You are on stage, in a cast and in pain because if you don't perform,
you wind up screwing the rest of the group in your entire cycle.
That sucks.
There's no workmen's compensation,  there's no sick-days
You've got to go out there and perform every day of your Life!
Part #2:
Privacy
What privacy?
If you sign up to be a K-pop idol, good luck having a dating life
Which seems to be something everyone forgets about.
I mean, wouldn't you want to date someone at some point in your life?
You're singing songs about boyfriends and girlfriends
and love, and life. But p.s. you're not allowed to date...
Based on what experience can you sing these songs?
And let's say you're dating ban has been lifted from you.
Are you just going to go out there and start dating?
Uh, NO! Because you may have crazy stalker fans that are going to  MURDER ANYONE YOU'RE TRYING TO DATE
And it doesn't seem to be any laws enforced.
We hear all these stories about sasaengs
Who I'm not going to call "Sasaeng fans", because they are just stalkers.
They're not fans.
There are no anti-stalking laws nor restraining orders.
You have no privacy ensured through the law if you are a K-pop idol.
And I'm sure you guys know what happened to Jonghyun from SHINee
when people found out he had a girlfriend.
People freaked out, made him feel horribly guilty, they knocked down her fan-site
He ended up crying on stage at one point somewhere and begging for forgiveness. and that's really nice guys...
So you are allowed to sing and dance about love,
but you are never allowed to actually experience it yourself.
Sucks!
Sucky!
Point #3:
Living together~
And a lot of people don't seem to consider this.
That a lot of these bands live together in dorms.
I'm not sure if you've experienced the same thing, but
living with other people can be difficult.
If you have a brother or a sister you might not necessarily like them all of the time.
If you're in college or you're out of college and you're renting a place and you've got friends
even if you're really close with them, there are going to be times when you're going to fight
and you're going to get on each other's nerves.
Now imagine: not only do you see each other every day at home,
but now you have to be in a van with them.
And you have to be backstage with them.
And you have to be with them All the Time!
I would imagine that once in a while you get on each other's nerves
Especially when someone goes into the kitchen and eats your last container of Ramyun
or maybe uses your pillow for their feet
Or uses your toothbrush in your ear.
Not everybody here is best friends for life.
There are a lot of tensions that go on off-screen.
But they always have to maintain this image if being Happy Best Friends Forever!
And sometimes living together really freakin sucks!
But not with us!
Because we're Best Friends For Life!
Just be careful because my tattoo is fresh!
Air hugs!
The point is: maintaining your social image on camera and on stage
and during interviews even if there could be inner turmoils
must be really freakin tough to do.
So those are major reasons why I would not want to be a K-pop idol
And I am sure there are many more that we don't know about,
Like if I looked up at one of the contracts I would probably run away screaming and crying
So scary... 7 years... Sign your like away...
It's me the Meems.
So a couple of things we just want to say is that having observed a lot of fan-forums
and reading different websites as well as our website
We see a lot of people saying things like
"Oh, this rookie group isn't getting recognition they deserve"
"Because they are working so hard and it's not fair"
But that argument doesn't work on us because everybody works hard.
All these K-pop idols have insane hours and insane schedules
and a lack of privacy.
So for us to pity one band over the other isn't fair.
Especially when people say things like "Oh, SNSD, Big Bang they've made it and it's unfair that they're getting recognition. They don't need it"
You think They didn't work hard when they started?
How much would it suck if you work for five years to be this band
and then people are like "Oh, well now that you're big, um... sorry"
"Sorry, we've got to give a chance to somebody else..."
So we're going to talk about a few more different points on our blog post
Make sure you clock on the link here if you want to see some more extra thoughts about this subject.
And I have a question for you guys:
Would you Still want to enter the K-pop world as an idol?
Because we Do get a lot of e-mails from people asking
Even though you know all of this information and a lot of you already know it without us telling you
Do you Still want to do it?
So what is it that's driving you?
I'm really curious to hear that from you guys.
For some people all these Cons are not bad enough to get them off the path
For us, I know that I value my time, I value my privacy more than fame and fortune.
So that's it for this week's TL;DR
If you have a question for next TL;DR leave your question in the comment section below
Or check out the questions already asked and you can thumb them up to bring them to our attention.
Or head over to our blog post and thumb up that post as well.
And don't forget to subscribe for more TL;DRs where we tell you more about Dongho's career as a Brazilian pirate
Speaking of normal lives... Hey Dongho, you're looking for a normal life?
Come here to work at the EatYourKimchi studio~
I'm sure you will Love working here.
We'll let you eat all the good stuff.
Yeah, you're going to get fan-mail.
You can be in our videos.
I'll make you coffee, I'll make you tea.
I've got a job waiting for you here.
There's a puppy and a kitty you can snuggle.
Give ma a call.
I'll hook you up?
You don't even need to speak English!

title: Dongho Quit Kpop, and Why We Would, Too

comments.text:
+Vixx Celacea
"I don't know why, and this might just be a stereotype, but I would swear 
there are far more devoted female fans of any group or idol then males. 
Perhaps males just don't gush about it the way females do though at least 
on average anyway."
       I think that's true of music as a whole. There definitely are some 
Male mega fans of rap and rock but nothing beats the devotion of a female 
pop fan any where in the world.
 Female fans are the reason Pop dominates over Rap and Rock.
comments.author: DarthNutz

comments.text:
+DarthNutz
Agreed. Could be true with the testosterone causing a more likely rise of 
physical expression of anger or possessiveness, but I think the degree of 
that varies from culture to culture. I'd like to know if relationship abuse 
severity and gender stereotypes is very similar to American or English 
speaking countries.

Women though can be extremely violent. As far as abuse goes, men being 
beaten by their wives or girlfriends in incredibly under talked about. Any 
form of abuse is terrible.

Men maybe more prone to violence due to genetics, but women have a sort of 
berserk button as it were when they perceive threat and that probably 
helped to equal out the lack of physical strength when we were more nomadic.

I don't know why, and this might just be a stereotype, but I would swear 
there are far more devoted female fans of any group or idol then males. 
Perhaps males just don't gush about it the way females do though at least 
on average anyway.
comments.author: Vixx “Sinvanor” Celacea

comments.text:
+Vixx Celacea
Given the intensity of female fans over male fans I guess it does make 
sense. I guess its like if Justin Bieber's or One Direction's fans were 
legally allowed to stalk them, which would be friggin insane. You would get 
every nutjob coming out the wood work. But with all that said I still think 
it would probably be more dangerous for the female kpop groups since male 
stalkers could potentially be more violent.
comments.author: DarthNutz

comments.text:
+DarthNutz I think the males have actually had it far harder. I've seen so 
many stories of boys from kpop bands being stalked, one of them even 
flipping out and telling a girl to fuck off.Stalkers are most likely 
mentally ill and probably not in an ego dystonic way (ego dystonic meaning 
that they can recognize they have a disorder, like how someone with OCD but 
not OCDP can.) There should DEFINITELY be laws about stalkers. That's just 
asking for someone to be hurt.
comments.author: Vixx “Sinvanor” Celacea

comments.text:
I think since you both are entertainment-adjacent, you empathize with them 
a lot more than most people. I get that the schedules are grueling and they 
have no private life, but an entertainer who complains about that is biting 
the hand that feeds them. 

When these stars were a nobody, they would do anything to have cameras 
taking their photos, and now they want privacy because they’ve grown 
comfortable with their level of fame? 

It’s not an industry for everyone, but if you want to engage your customers 
(fans are customers, don’t think otherwise), you can’t get mad that they're 
engaging back. 

That being said, you can choose distance yourself when you need to and 
engage when you want to. Don’t announce that you have a girlfriend on stage 
if you don’t want people telling you what they think about it. 

The best part is that you can just quit if it’s too much. There are a 
million people that can replace you, and a million jobs you can excel at 
too! ﻿
comments.author: Nakul B

Asian fans are so stupid! They take shit to far!! its like who are if a

comments.text:
+MAJE5TYY "You said it yourself that you were offended you fucking idiot. 
Jesus Christ..." LOL made me smile. Completely agree with you, btw.
comments.author: 123itstime4tea

comments.text:
It's funny you edited your post so you would look less stupid using 
condescending and analogies wrong. And deleted 80% of your assumptions. 
Hilarious.

You still look stupid. And yes, it seems like you do give a really big fat 
fuck. You're saying you don't observe things then? Figures since thinking 
and basic skills requires that. I think you're still having trouble 
defining analogy.  Maybe condescending will be easier to understand.
comments.author: MAJE5TYY

comments.text:
+MAJE5TYY Oh, I'm sorry, was I supposed to give a fuck?
I just commented here to say that there are Americans who take shit so far 
and fangirls being fangirls. And now I'm arguing with an unreasonable fuck. 
Goodbye.

And to answer your question (so I don't leave you looking stupid), 
analogies uses observation. I don't have to say the rest. Do you not know? 
Oh wait, that's why you were asking. Whoops. Bye, your "maje5tyy" or 
whatever that means.
comments.author: Ylai Jah

comments.text:
+Ylai Jah I'm sure fan pages being taken down are fake and singers having 
their career ruined publicly is fake, and girls getting kicked out is fake. 
Obviously it's a long running April Fools joke that lasts permanently. I 
didn't blame "Asians" it's the culture. Like I said, sure, some girls get 
angry, but in the West, it's not a big deal. Justin Bieber's career didn't 
end when he started dating Selena, and vice versa. I never said you were a 
fangirl. You said it yourself that you were offended you fucking idiot. 
Jesus Christ your post consists of incorrect assumptions. The amount of 
bullshit in your post is so far up your ass it's leaked into your head if 
you think majority of what you said was implied in my post(p.s. they 
weren't since critically thinking seems too far up the alley for you).

Also you used condescending wrong. What does being a detective have to do 
with analogies? Do you not know what that word means either?
comments.author: MAJE5TYY

comments.text:
+MAJE5TYY 
"I wouldn't say it's influenced by the fans themselves but how the company 
wants to portrays their idols. If the companies allowed them to date openly 
and everyone came out with who they were dating it would gradually be a 
social norm."
This is the only thing I agree on your comment.
"It's SK culture," Lol. Bullshit.
It's idol culture. Not "SK." Idol culture is pretty much everywhere and 
there are many other stupid fangirls in the world doing lots of crazy 
things.
If you actually think I'm an offended "fangirl" who's trying to defend some 
country then you're an idiot as well. You people are the ones that take 
these shit seriously.It seems I offended you that much for you to type a 
stupid comment.
comments.author: Ylai Jah

comments.text:
+Ylai Jah No, it's SK culture. If stars date it's not a big deal in the US. 
It's not a scandal, and it doesn't ruin their careers. In SK it's a giant 
deal. Zayn and Perrie was a big thing because it was a cheating scandal, 
not dating. Justin Bieber is one of the biggest stars in the world right 
now, are you really comparing him to some band only known to SK and like 
0.01% of the world's population? If you feel offended because of a 
generalization then you're an idiot. By no means can dating in the West can 
compare with k-pop idols. And by the way, most "wrist slitting" was fake. 
Singer shot on stage. That wasn't a fan you dimwit. You're comparing such a 
little % of Western extremist fans, to a large percentage of what is the 
NORM for kpopfans. Oh all universities aren't safe because of Virginian 
Tech! You act like getting shot on stage is a frequent/normal thing that 
happens all the time like kpop idols having a scandal over dating. It's a 
fucking norm for kpop to have scandals over dating. How are you going to 
compare a couple hundred girls on Twitter pretending to cut themselves out 
of millions of fans, to an entire kpop fan base?Your analogies are a joke. 
Kpop idols are ostracized and compared and rated for every petty thing. 
While in the West you like them for their individuality and if you 
ostracize them you're pretty much seen as an airhead for even caring about 
what they do. 

I wouldn't say it's influenced by the fans themselves but how the company 
wants to portrays their idols. If the companies allowed them to date openly 
and everyone came out with who they were dating it would gradually be a 
social norm. But due to the companies it was pushed out of a accepted norm. 
But even with SK culture they don't exactly have a lot of PDA.
comments.author: MAJE5TYY

comments.text:
+Hajirah Omar Nah..you don't sound racist. You make a lot of sense actually 
^^
comments.author: Shannon Williams

comments.text:
you had to consider a particular race and had the ignorance to insult 
them. I do agree with a lot of things that you say, but Western fans can 
also go as far as these "stupid Asian fans."
Like, Dimebag's lead singer getting shot in the head while performing, One 
Direction fangirls cutting themselves and killing their dogs.
Pretty much we are all human, and when you turn into a fan you become as 
idiotic as the others. And not just because you are Asian.
When Justin Bieber was dating with Selena Gomez, the same thing happens. As 
well as with Zayn Malik and Perrie (or whatever her name was). 
This all happens in the industry. Fangirls are fangirls.
comments.author: Ylai Jah

comments.text:
+Hajirah Omar
 I think that might more be because those girls can get away with it, or 
it's the stories we most hear about. They seem to have a real stalking 
problem over there. Even getting a name for it.
Oh, don't worry. I'm the kinda person that agrees that unfortunately 
stereotypes exist and some people exemplify why some forms of racism are 
even around. Perhaps I just felt like "Asian fans are so stupid" was too 
much of a blanket statement.
I only wanted to point out that there might be an underlying cause to it, 
that Korean culture doesn't seem to care. Like it's the norm to have 
clearly mental teenage girls who need help because obsession is a very 
unhealthy behavior. Instead the industry just demands they take it with 
grace and poise and they're fired if they don't. I think one other 
contributing factor is the sheer amount of incredibly famous idols that 
exist. Justin Beiber is popular the world over and there's only about what, 
7 other really famous boy bands like that? Where as Kpop has far more, 
there is more to focus and hone in on, not to mention many of them aren't 
even known outside of Korea. Basically, the asian specifically female fans 
are terrible more because of culture and the way kpop is handled, as 
opposed to simply being Asian, since Asian includes all other Asians, not 
just Koreans. I don't know if Japan, China, Vietnam and others have issues 
like this with their idols.

For the record, I think a lot of closed off countries, like SK get a kind 
of attitude that foreigners are stupid unfortunately :( Not all of them of 
course, but clearly a large amount with in the kpop fandom.
We hate or fear what we're not apart of and don't understand. And that 
sucks.
comments.author: Vixx “Sinvanor” Celacea

comments.text:
+Hajirah Omar Thank you!! most of the time is Asian girls! TBH dating 
someone is not really a big deal! and also in some k dramas it also show 
when girls go crazy and attack the idol's girlfriend. to all the stupid 
fans (sorry to say this but is true, hate when fans make a big deal) when 
is it right for kpop/actors to start dating? Hope all the Asian fans read 
this!! and also some girls all over the world that make a big deal that 
their idol are dating! NOT A BI DEAL!!!
comments.author: miss katt

comments.text:
+Vixx Celacea actually, from what I have seen, the majority of the fans 
who've gone crazy after seeing their favourite idol in a relationship with 
another idol are the Asian fans. This is based off of my experiences and 
what I have seen. When that one guy who's name I've forgotten from Suju got 
married, the fans who were giving them hate mail were like 75% Asian. Yeah 
it's negative, but is it really racist? It's an assumption that has 
something to do with race, just because it's negative and involves race 
doesn't mean it's racist. (BTW I hope I'm not sounding like a jerk or 
anything. I'm being sincere here and as a middle eastern Muslim I've felt 
racism directed towards me) In fact some Korean english speakers translated 
some of the comments. I saw comments of people saying racist things towards 
international fans because most of the I ternation fans still supported him 
and they said stuff like "They're too dumb to know what we're saying 
anyways" there was also a fair amount of hate direction towards Saudi 
Arabian ELFS I think? Don't know where that came from... but I think it 
would be fair to say that most saesengs and other haters are Asian. Again, 
really sorry if it sounds racist :/ Tbh with you though I have seen some 
western fans expressing hate over their relationships as well, but it's 
like a once in a blue moon kind of thing. Very rare, but it does happen!
comments.author: Hajirah Omar

comments.text:
+miss katt It's not remotely just asians, that's a little racist, but I can 
understand why you thought that. I think it's more that there are no rules 
in place in Asia for this kinda thing, at least not in SK. But I've seen 
PLENTY of english speaking girls being pissed about a star whether music or 
acting or anything being in a relationship or marrying. People often become 
extremely possessive if they're already a bit unstable. This happens with 
idols more times then I can count. Personally, I don't think idol-dom is 
healthy, for either the idols or the fans. Mentally they become gods to 
many.

comments.text:
+123itstime4tea Yeah I can see that. A lot of their like really preppy 
upbeat cutesy pop songs sound similar. But for ballads and the less upbeat 
songs it's a lot better in terms of difference(even then a lot of featured 
ballads sound the same). Another part could be because you don't understand 
Korean either(since lyrics are a large part of the songs, if you don't know 
what they're saying then it'll all just sound the same and alike) which 
includes a lot of people that listens to K-Pop.
comments.author: MAJE5TYY

comments.text:
+MAJE5TYY Yeah, that's true. But my sentiment about a lot of their sounds 
being similar to each other is echoed through out South Korea itself. A lot 
of Koreans (including artists themselves) acknowledge similar sounding 
K-Pop songs as an actual problem in that genre. But I know that there are 
many artists that are actually talented and write their own stuff.
comments.author: 123itstime4tea

comments.text:
+123itstime4tea Everyone has a different style, different songs. There's 
variety to their music as well, but you're literally talking about K-POP, 
you know, the POP, part? It's 1 genre. Just because a group looks 
physically the same as another doesn't mean they'll release the same songs.
comments.author: MAJE5TYY

comments.text:

comments.text:

talented artists. If you're saying these songs are different, then I'll 
believe you. I'm just saying that the industry as a whole is pretty 
homogeneous in its musical flavor and concepts.
comments.author: 123itstime4tea

comments.text:
+123itstime4tea +sophomore90 I see your point, but not all Kpop groups are 
cookie cutter. 2NE1 has some great stuff that wasn't really precedented in 
Kpop--they're the real "tough girl" group. And Megan Lee's new song 
"8Dayz". And Lee Hi's, "It's Over" and "1.2.3.4." TVXQ's "Something" has a 
much older style to it. "I Hope" by FT Island. "Doom Dada" by T.O.P. is a 
really good rap song, but the video is super weird. Amber's, "Beautiful". 
They're all different styles. It depends on which groups, or even songs, 
you listen to.
comments.author: irockleftsocks13405

comments.text:
+Vera Colley  I disagree; there's a lot of diversity and variety in 
American music- even in pop alone. I've had many friends who've idolized 
Kpop artists over the years, and I agree with sophomore; a lot of them are 
cookie-cutters of one another. Sure, over the years I've come to 
distinguish a few styles here and there... but for the most part- it's the 
same. That's what happens when you have third parties writing your music, 
lyrics, and choreographing your dances. Few concepts end up being original.
comments.author: 123itstime4tea

comments.text:
I think you should look a bit of the western music... It's basically all

Honestly I can 100% understand why Kris and Luhan left exo. I knew the Kpop

to 3 hours of sleep a night. Also it seems there is alot of bulling not

members. I am not sure if any of that is true but I could see it being 
true. Even if Kpop idols have no you can not date rule in their contract, 
when do they even have the time. And their health omg i am suprised how 
some of them are not hospitalized for months. Not enough sleep, poor diet,

body (even if they are young guys).﻿

comments.author: Sosmcs See

comments.text:
It’s kind of long, sorry =(

You nailed “no fortune, just fame” idea down. In my opinion, the way this 
industry is crafted doesn’t encourage or even allow for Idols to access 
their creative potential. In fact, I have a hard time considering K-pop 
Idols as artists. I view them as products because of how much control their 
company has on their work and lives in general. Sure, there are those token 
artists who actually write their own music, but for the most part, Idols 
are money-machines for their companies. 

I’m not going to explain it all here. For more solid figures on Idols’ 
salaries (which isn’t much), you can just google it. This particular link 
takes you to an article that tries to remain unbiased. IMO, the best part 
is the comments; they are written by people who know quite a bit about the 
industry, as well as the opinions of those who’ve lived in Korea.

http://beyondhallyu.com/k-pop/k-pop-slave-contracts-a-closer-look/
comments.author: 123itstime4tea

comments.text: If u could tell me just briefly how it works, I'd appreciate it 😊
comments.author: Sosmcs See

comments.text:
One of my friends who's previously worked in the Kpop industry explained to 
me the salaries (or fortune) of Kpop stars. It's a pretty structured system 
that's very different from how artists make money in the States. While it 
has its benefits, it's definitely not something I envy.
comments.author: 123itstime4tea

That's a huge generalisation. I don't see what is such a crime about not 
understanding the lyrics. What is wrong with enjoying music in another 
language? I recently got into kpop and I am constantly searching up the 
translated lyrics and I am learning Korean so that I will be able to 
understand the songs without translations. But there is absolutely nothing 
shameful in not understanding the lyrics and having a preference for music 
in a language foreign to you. Besides, I highly doubt that "most don't even 
understand the lyrics" because most kpop are fans are in fact Korean.

comments.text:
I have wanted to be a kpop idol for years now, and even as I hear about the 
conditions and such of the idol lifestyle, I still want to.  I went through 
a rough time in my life, and music was always the only thing that I could 
turn to.  At the worst point in my life, I found kpop. I had quit dancing, 
I had stopped singing and I was just having a really horrible time.  Kpop 
made me remember that there ARE things fun in life.  It got me back into 
dancing which helped me lose weight be healthier.  The more I listened to 
kpop, the more I danced, the more I got fully back into singing, I became 
happy. I can't, to this day, think of a time before kpop that I was 
actually genuinely happy.  The music actually helped me. I have been around 
music my whole life, and I know how important it is to have music.  Since 
kpop helped me through the worst time in my life, I really want to make 
music and perform for people, and I hope that maybe, even if it's just one 
person, that I can help someone realize that there's something happy in 
life.  I have met such amazing people through kpop, and I can't imagine 
where I would be right now if I hadn't found the thing that finally made me 
happy. I can't picture myself doing anything different.  I love singing. I 
love dancing. I love performing. I love making people happy. It's hard 
being in the US and trying to do this, but if all goes as planned, I will 
be in SK by the end of this year. I can almost fully understand Korean, and 
I can speak a good amount.  No matter what I hear about kpop and being an 
idol that may be negative, it won't ever change the fact that I seriously 
can't imagine my life a different way and I really want to make people 
happy and hopefully help at least one person to smile, just as kpop helped 
me. I've never been happier in my life and I hope, someday, someone will 
smile and be happy listening to me or watching me on stage.﻿
comments.author: Nicole Ruiz

comments.text:
Brazilian pirate? That is new. I am Brazilian, so I am half way there 
ARRRR!! heheheeh I wanna be a pirate now﻿
comments.author: João Paulo Stanzioni

comments.text: OMG I'd totally work at EYK any day XD﻿
comments.author: Olivia Widjaja

comments.text:
Not to equate the situation or anything. I think medic students also have 
it tough. I think at some point of your life if you want to do something, 
you will only have it the hard way. these kind of things are ultimately 
choices. If you're passionate enough then when it is so hard you know why 
you have to keep going. Because you love doing it. Other than that, I think 
before we're committed into something we really have to do a thorough 
research of what awaits you. Life is not all shiny and bling bling. As a 
fellow human, I do sympathize them, but it is their choice to be a 
performer. Nothing comes free in this world. Things are harder when your 
work is along the line in which you have to constantly please people. Cause 
you know why? People are so inconsistent and judgemental. ﻿
comments.author: abthurd

comments.text:
I'm curious, does Korea not have an equivalent of a Department of Labor 
that sets standards and labor laws?  Are there no labor laws in Korea at 
all?  K-pop idols have already won in the courts against the entertainment 
companies.  It seems as though the issues of the treatment of K-pop idols 
is commonly known in Korea.  I am surprised that someone has not stepped 
forward politically to try and reign in how the industry works.  Especially 
since it involves what we in the west would consider minors/children under 
legal age of adulthood or consent in many cases.

I would hate to see the K-pop music industry turn into what we have in the 
West, but I think it is in the best interest of both parties if the artist 
has more say-so in their working conditions.  I understand that in a lot of 
cases, the entertainment companies have spent millions getting their artist 
ready for debut, and they deserve to be able to make that money back and to 
also make a fair profit.  I feel that after their initial contract, the 
artist should have the ability to negotiate a contract that is more 
friendly to the group or artist which could put standards and limits on 
their work conditions and compensation.

The current model is working well for the entertainment companies, but is 
teetering really close to indentured servitude for the artist.  I love the 
K-pop idols in the groups that I like, and I want them to have long and 
productive careers....I don't want them worked to death.﻿

comments.text:
There might be some pressure to do really well since they train for many 
years before debuting so if they left it would screw the rest of the 
members over... I think a lot of the idols go into the industry thinking 
they know what they're getting themselves into, but right when they do get 
into it really does hit them like "shit, i'm going to be doing this for x 
years". I think if you're doing something that you truly love then you 
won't mind enduring it. Even if that means dealing with crazy stalkers and 
limited hours of sleep..i'm not all down with it but some companies need to 
realize that they need to take care of their idols more properly since 
they're the company's source of revenue.﻿

comments.author: Tiana Rua

comments.text:
It might sound glamorous, but it will slowly consume you. The pay isn't 
even that great. The only thing you are gaining in abundance is fame. And 
fame itself does not appeal to me. If it does to you, then it would be 
perfect for you.

Edit: Just wanted to add that you also lose the most important things in 
life. Time with family and friends, downtime, traveling the world, meeting 
new people interested in you and not your status, and generally just life...
